Highly active and long lived homogeneous catalyst for the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate and oleylamine precatalyst Sibel Duman a Mehdi Masjedi b Saim Özkar b ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Bingol University, Bingol 12000, Turkey Department of Chemistry Bingol University Bingol 12000 Turkey b Department of Chemistry, Middle East Technical University, Ankara 06800, Turkey Department of Chemistry Middle East Technical University Ankara 06800 Turkey ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +90 312 210 3200. Graphical abstract Herein, we report the results of our study on the homogeneous catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in the presence of Ru(acac)3 and oleylamine (OAm) in toluene solution. The precatalyst system comprising Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent OAm shows the high catalytic activity in hydrogen generation from dimethylamine borane solution. Monitoring the hydrogen evolution shows the presence of an induction period during which the homogeneous catalyst is formed, and then the hydrogen evolution continues almost linearly until the complete dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. UV–vis spectroscopic observation implies on the formation of a ruthenium(II) species. Using UV–vis, FTIR, Mass, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopies we could identify the presence of trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] in the solid residue obtained after the catalytic reaction. This complex might be a stable form of the active catalyst as it shows similar catalytic activity in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane as before. The precatalyst system comprising Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent OAm provides 15,000 turnovers over 8 days with a constant turnover frequency of TOF=77.8h−1 in hydrogen generation from the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene solution at 60.0±0.1°C. Adding 3 equivalent OAm per Ru into the precatalyst solution increases the catalytic activity by a factor of ∼5 and the lifetime of the catalyst by a factor of >9 compared to the ones obtained by using sole Ru(acac)3. Kinetics of catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent OAm in toluene solution were studied depending on catalyst concentration, substrate concentration and temperature. The catalytic reaction was found to be first-order with respect to each of both Ru(acac)3 and dimethylamine borane concentrations. The activation energy for the catalytic dehydrogenation is E a =58±2kJ/mol. Keywords Ruthenium acetylacetonate Oleylamine Hydrogen generation Dimethylamine borane Dehydrogenation Homogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction Catalytic dehydrocoupling of amine-borane adducts has become increasingly important from the perspective of current interest in hydrogen storage [1–3], as the efficient storage of hydrogen is still the key issue in hydrogen economy on the way towards a sustainable energy future [4,5]. Of particular importance is the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane (Me2NH·BH3), which can release hydrogen in the presence of suitable catalyst under mild conditions (Eq. (1)) [6–8]. (1) A number of catalysts have recently been employed in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane [9]: IrCl3, RhCl(PPh3)3, [Cp*Rh(μ-Cl)Cl2], [Rh(1,5-cod)2OTf], [Rh(1,5-cod)(dmpe)]PF6, HRh(CO)(PPh3)3, trans-RuMe2(PMe3)4 and trans-PdCl2(P(o-tolyl)3)2 [8] Ru(H)(PMe3)(PNP) and trans-Ru(H)2(PMe3)(PNPH) [10]; [Rh(1,5-cod)(μ-Cl)]2 [11–14]; [Cp2Ti] [15–17]; [RuH2(η2-H2)2(PCy3)2] and [RuH2(η2:η2-H2B-N(Me2)2(PCy3)2] [18]; RhCl3, Rhcolloid/[Oct4N]Cl and Rh(Al2O3) [12]; laurate-stabilized Rh(0) [19]; dimethylammonium hexanoate stabilized Rh(0) [20]; aminopropyltriethoxysilane stabilized Ru(0) [21]; oleylamine stabilized Ru(0) [22], rhenium complexes [23]; Rh4-6 clusters [24], RhCl(PHCy2)3 [25], RuNPs/ZIF-8 [26], [Ru(p-Cym)(bipy)Cl]Cl [27], Pd(0)/MOF [28], amylamine stabilized Pd(0) [29]. Prompted by the observation that ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate, Ru(acac)3 acts as homogeneous catalyst in the hydrolysis of sodium borohydride at room temperature [30], we have very recently shown that dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane can also be catalyzed starting with sole Ru(acac)3 in toluene solution at temperature above 50°C [31]. Although we were unable to isolate and thoroughly characterize the active catalyst formed in this reaction we have shown that a new ruthenium(II) species bearing two N-ligands is formed from the reduction of ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate during catalytic reaction. The ruthenium(II) species was tried to be stabilized by adding suitable stabilizers such as trimethylphosphite (P(OMe)3) and oleylamine (OAm). A ruthenium(II) species containing trimethylphosphite ligands could be identified in catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 and P(OMe)3 similar to the ruthenium complex isolated after hydrolysis of sodium borohydride in the presence of Ru(acac)3 and P(OMe)3 [32]. Since the presence of trimethylphosphite lowers the catalytic activity we decided to test oleylamine as stabilizer. In literature, there are reports concerning the use of oleylamine (C18H37N) as surfactant in the synthesis of NiO nanoparticles [33] or monodisperse Ni nanoparticles [34,35], as reducing agent in the synthesis of magnetite nanoparticles [22,36] or colloidal NiPt nanoparticles [37], as protectant in preparation of ferromagnetic SmCo5 [38], Ir nanocrystals [39]. However, there is no report concerning the use of oleylamine as stabilizing ligand for homogeneous catalysis resulting in coordination of oleylamine to metal. Since our recent paper [31] has reported the identification of a ruthenium(II) species bearing two N-ligands in the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 we decided to add oleylamine as N-ligand for the stabilization of active catalyst in this reaction. Herein, we report the use of oleylamine as stabilizing agent in catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 which leads to the formation of a novel homogeneous ruthenium catalyst containing oleylamine ligands, trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2], characterized by UV–vis, FTIR, 1H and 13C NMR, and mass spectroscopies. Our report also includes the results of catalytic tests using Ru(acac)3 plus oleylamine in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene solution as well as the results of the kinetic study of the catalytic reaction depending on the catalyst concentration, substrate concentration and temperature. The results reported here clearly show the novelty of the present study. Of particular importance is that adding 3 equivalent oleylamine per mole of ruthenium into the precatalyst solution of Ru(acac)3 increases the catalytic activity by a factor of ∼5 and the lifetime of the catalyst by a factor of >9 compared to the ones obtained by using sole Ru(acac)3 [31] in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene at 60.0±0.1°C. Another interesting feature of the present study is the simplicity of preparing the catalytic materials as the precatalyst system reported here is composed of a ruthenium compound and a stabilizer ligand, both of which are commercially available. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate (97%), borane-dimethylamine complex (97%), trimethylphosphite (≥99.0%), oleylamine (70%), toluene (99.7%) and hexane (99%) were purchased from Aldrich®. Dichloromethane (99%) was purchased from Merck® and THF was purchased from Fluka. All glassware and Teflon coated magnetic stir bars were cleaned with acetone, followed by copious rinsing with distilled water before drying at 150°C for a few hours. 2.2 Equipment The experimental setup used for performing the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane under argon or nitrogen atmospheres and measuring the hydrogen gas generated from the reaction consists of a 50mL jacketed reaction flask containing a Teflon-coated stir bar placed on a magnetic stirrer (IKA® RCT Basic) and thermostated by circulating water through its jacket from a constant temperature bath (RL6 LAUDA water bath). A graduated glass tube (50cm in height and 2.5cm in diameter) filled with water was connected to the reaction flask to measure the volume of the hydrogen gas to be evolved from the reaction. Measuring the total turnover number (TTON) was performed in a Parr-5101 low pressure stirred reactor with a circulating water-bath for constant temperature control under inert gas atmosphere. The Parr-5101 low-pressure stirred reactor was connected with a digital transmitter to a computer using a RS-232 module. The progress of an individual dehydrogenation reaction was followed by monitoring the increase in the pressure of hydrogen gas with the program Calgrafix. The temperature was also controlled via a thermocouple placed inside the reactor. NMR spectrums were measured on a Bruker Avance (III) 400MHz spectrometer and chemical shifts are given in ppm (δ) relative to Me4Si as internal standard. Electronic absorption spectra were generated at room temperature in a 1cm quartz cuvette using a Shimadzu-2450 double beam spectrometer with a 20μL solution and a spectral range of 200–800nm. The infrared spectrum was recorded from a Vertex 70 ATR/FTIR spectrometer. Positive ion mass spectrometry data was acquired on a Micro TOF-LC/ESI/Ms system. 2.3 Catalytic activity of Ru(acac)3 in the presence of oleylamine in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane A stock solution of 15mM oleylamine in toluene was prepared by dissolving 0.26mL oleylamine (MW=267.50g/mol) in 5mL toluene. For the preparation of catalyst solution with [OAm]/[Ru] ratio of 3, an aliquot of the stock solution was added to the reaction solution. In a glass vial, certain amount of dimethylamine borane (in the range of 0.2–2M) was dissolved in 5mL toluene. In the reactor given amount of Ru(acac)3 corresponding to the final concentration of 2.5–50mM plus 3 equivalents of oleylamine per ruthenium are dissolved in 5.0mL toluene at 60.0±0.1°C under inert atmosphere. After addition of dimethylamine borane solution into the reactor, the reaction was started by closing the reactor and turning on the stirrer at 1000rpm simultaneously. The hydrogen generation was measured by recording the water level in graduated glass tube, which is connected to the reaction flask, in every 5min. Kinetics of dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane catalyzed by Ru(acac)3 in the presence of oleylamine were studied depending on substrate concentration, catalyst concentration and temperature. In a set of experiments, dimethylamine borane concentrations were held constant at 0.5–1.0M, and Ru(acac)3 concentrations plus 3 equivalents of oleylamine per ruthenium was varied in the range of 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, 10mM and 7.5, 10, 15, 20mM, respectively, at 60.0±0.1°C. In the second set of experiments, Ru(acac)3 concentrations plus 3 equivalents of oleylamine per ruthenium were held constant at 5.0 or 20mM while dimethylamine borane concentrations were varied in the range 0.20–2.0M at 60.0±0.1°C. In the third set of experiments, Ru(acac)3 concentrations of both 5.0 and 20mM plus 3 equivalents of oleylamine per ruthenium were performed by keeping dimethylamine borane concentration constant at 0.5 or 1.0M and varying the temperature in the range of 50, 55, 60, 65 and 70°C in order to obtain the activation energy, enthalpy of activation, and entropy of activation for the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. The pressure versus time data was processed using Microsoft Office Excel 2007 and Origin 8.0 and then converted into the values in the proper unit, volume of hydrogen (mL). 2.4 Catalytic lifetime of Ru(acac)3 in the presence of oleylamine in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane The catalytic lifetime of Ru(acac)3 in the presence of oleylamine in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane was determined by calculating the total turnover number (TON). Such a lifetime experiment was performed in the Parr-5101 reactor starting with a 10mL solution containing 5.0mM Ru(acac)3, 0.5M dimethylamine borane in the presence of 3 equivalents of oleylamine per ruthenium at 60.0±0.1°C. When 75% of hydrogen generation was achieved, more dimethylamine borane was added to the reaction solution. By this way, the addition of dimethylamine borane was repeated until no more hydrogen gas was evolved. 2.5 Poisoning experiment of Ru(acac)3 in the presence of oleylamine in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane In order to understand whether dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane catalyzed by Ru(acac)3 in the presence of oleylamine is homogenous or heterogeneous, mercury poisoning experiment was carried out [40]. After the 50% conversion of reaction was attained, 700 equivalent of mercury per ruthenium was added to the reaction solution including 5.0mM Ru(acac)3, 0.5M dimethylamine borane in presence of 3 equivalents of oleylamine per ruthenium. The hydrogen generation rate was not changed after the addition of mercury, indicating that this reaction is indeed homogeneous catalysis. 2.6 Isolation and characterization of trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] A stock solution of 15mM oleylamine in toluene was prepared by dissolving 0.26mL oleylamine (MW=267.50g/mol) in 5mL toluene. For the preparation of catalyst solution with [OAm]/[Ru] ratio of 3, an aliquot of the stock solution was diluted to 1mL by adding toluene and, then, in a glass vial 19.9mg (0.050mmol) Ru(acac)3 was dissolved in 1mL toluene solution containing 3 equivalent oleylamine under stirring. Then, the solution was transferred into the reaction flask containing 294.6mg (5.0mmol) dimethylamine borane dissolved in 9mL toluene and thermostated at 60.0±0.1°C. The initial concentrations of Ru(acac)3 and oleylamine in the reaction solution were 5.0 and 15.0mM, respectively. The reaction was started by closing the reactor and turning on the stirrer at 1000rpm simultaneously. The reaction was continued for 2h under inert atmosphere and followed by UV–vis spectroscopic measurements. After 2h stirring, the solvent was evaporated in vacuum and the residue was dissolved in the mixture of hexane–dichloromethane. Then, the mixture was cooled in order to precipitate out dimethylamine borane and the cyclic product formed during dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. At the next step, the solution was filtered and evaporated in vacuum giving about 40mg bright brown solid residue containing trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] complex, which was found to be soluble in tetrahydrofuran (THF), but only slightly soluble in other organic solvents. Selected data for trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2]: 1H NMR (400MHz, THF-d8, ppm): δ 0.76 (s, 6H, CH3 (OAm)), 1.21 (m, 40H, CH2 (OAm)), 1.42 (m, 4H, CH3 CH 2 (OAm)), 1.65 (m, 4H, CH2 CH2 NH2 (OAm)), 1.77 (s, 8H, CH2 CC (OAm)), 2.82 (m, 4H, NCH2 (OAm)), 3.74 (s, 12H, OCH3 (acac)) 4.57 (d, 4H (OAm) + 2H (acac), CH), 7.05 (s, 4H, NH2 (OAm)). 13C NMR (400MHz, THF/CDCl3, ppm): δ 13.37 (CH3 (OAm)), 21.45–32.88 (CH2 (OAm)), 46.22 (N CH2 (OAm)), 64.51 and 66.03 (CH3 (acac)), 97.52 (CH (acac)), 129.90 and 130.91 (CH CH (OAm)), 160.56 (C O (acac)). FTIR (neat, υ ¯ , cm−1): 3318–3205 (br m, NH2 (strch)), 2957–2851 (s, CH (strch)), 1626 (m, CC (strch)), 1560 (w, NH2 (scissor)), 1516–1313 (br s, CO), 1463 (w, CH (bend)), 1076 (s, C N (strch)), 920–1020 (s, NH (bend)), 650–900 (s, NH (wagging)). UV (Toluene, nm): λ max 288 and 355. Mass: m/z 834.56 (M+, 100%), simulation m/z 834.57. 2.7 Catalytic activity of solid residue containing trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine-borane To testing of the catalytic activity of brown solid residue containing trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] complex in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine-borane were performed in 5mL of THF in which dimethylamine-borane (0.20M) and brown solid residue containing trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] complex (8.34mg) are dissolved at 60.0±0.1°C. Then, the reaction was started by closing the reactor and turning on the stirrer at 1000rpm simultaneously. The volume of hydrogen gas generated was recorded every 5min. 3 Results and discussions The catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane was performed starting with Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent oleylamine (OAm) or 2 equivalent trimethylphosphite (P(OMe)3) per mole of ruthenium to test their stabilizing effect on the active catalyst formed from the reduction of the precursor ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate. Fig. 1 shows the plots of equivalent H2 per mole of dimethylamine borane versus time for the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane (0.5M) in the presence of (a) 5.0mM Ru(acac)3 alone, (b) 5.0mM Ru(acac)3 plus 3 equivalent oleylamine, and (c) 5.0mM Ru(acac)3 plus 2 equivalent trimethylphosphite in 10.0mL toluene at 60.0±0.1°C. While in the presence of oleylamine one observes a hydrogen generation profile similar to that obtained by the sole Ru(acac)3 [31], though with a shorter induction time during which the catalyst is formed, the trimethylphosphite has completely different effect on the kinetics of reaction, an effect similar to one observed in the case of hydrogen generation from the hydrolysis of sodium borohydride [41,32]. A hydrogen generation starts at the same rate as in the case of sole Ru(acac)3, but continues only for 15min and then ceases for 85min, which would imply that the trimethylphosphite acts as poison. However, the hydrogen generation restarts after 100min at a rate of 1.5mL H2 /min, which is much slower than the rate of 3.3mL H2 /min obtained in the case of sole Ru(acac)3. During the induction time, trimethylphosphite reacts with ruthenium(II) species forming a catalytically active species. Since the addition of P(OMe)3 has an overall negative effect on the kinetics, we decided to use oleylamine for stabilizing the ruthenium(II) species formed during the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in the presence of Ru(acac)3. The next issue is to determine the optimum concentration of oleylamine for obtaining the highest catalytic activity and stability. Fig. 2 a shows the results of experiments performed starting with 0.5M solution of dimethylamine borane and 5.0mM Ru(acac)3 plus 1, 2, 3, or 4 equivalent oleylamine per mole of ruthenium in 10.0mL toluene at 60.0±0.1°C. The rate of hydrogen generation obtained from the linear portion of each curve is plotted against the mole ratio of oleylamine to ruthenium (Fig. 2b) showing that the maximum activity is obtained when 3 equivalent oleylamine is added into the solution per mole of ruthenium. Therefore, 3 equivalents of oleylamine per mole of ruthenium were added into the reaction solution in all of the further dehydrogenation experiments in this study. Catalytic activity of the system comprising Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent oleylamine in the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane shows expectedly dependence on the initial ruthenium concentration. Fig. 3 depicts the plots of mole hydrogen per mole dimethylamine borane versus time during dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane performed starting with constant substrate concentrations of 0.5M (Fig. 3a) or 1.0M (Fig. 3b), and various concentration of Ru(acac)3 plus 3 equivalent oleylamine per mole of ruthenium at 60.0±0.1°C. The inspection of the plots displayed in Fig. 3 reveals the following points: (i) One observes a short induction period during which the catalytically active species is formed from the reduction of Ru(acac)3 in the presence of oleylamine. (ii) The hydrogen generation increases during the induction period and then continues almost linearly until the complete consumption of dimethylamine borane present in the reaction solution. (iii) The induction time for the formation of active catalyst decreases with the increasing concentration of Ru(acac)3. (iv) On the contrary to this, the catalytic activity during the induction time increases with the increasing concentration of Ru(acac)3. (v) After the induction time, the rate of hydrogen generation, obtained from the slope of the linear portion of plots, increases with the increasing concentration of Ru(acac)3. Insets in Fig. 3a and b show the plots of initial rate of hydrogen generation versus the initial concentration of ruthenium, both on logarithmic scale. The linear fits of both plots give a slope of about 1.1, indicating that dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane is first-order with respect to the concentration of Ru(acac)3. The hydrogen generation rate could also be calculated from the linear portion of plots after induction period in Fig. 3. However, since the concentration of active catalyst is not known as the conversion of ruthenium(III) to ruthenium(II) continues (vide infra), a plot similar to the one for initial rates in Fig. 3 cannot be drawn. The effect of substrate concentration on the hydrogen generation rate was also investigated by varying the concentration of dimethylamine borane at constant ruthenium concentrations of 5.0mM (Fig. 4 a) and 20mM (Fig. 4b) in presence of 3 equivalent oleylamine per mole of ruthenium at 60.0±0.1°C. The plots of initial rate of hydrogen generation versus dimethylamine borane concentration (both in logarithmic scale) in the inset of Fig. 4a and b give straight line with a slope of about 1.2 and 0.8, respectively. This indicates that dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane is also first order with respect to the substrate concentration. Dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane was carried out at various temperatures in the range 50–70°C starting with a solution containing 0.5M dimethylamine borane and 5.0mM Ru(acac)3 (Fig. 5 a) and 1.0M dimethylamine borane and 20mM Ru(acac)3 (Fig. 5b) plus 3 equivalents of oleylamine per mole of ruthenium in 10mL toluene. The examination of the plots in Fig. 5 reveals the following points: (i) The induction time for the formation of active catalyst decreases with the increasing temperature. (ii) The catalytic activity increases with the increasing temperature both during and after the induction period. The values of the rate constant k were determined from the linear portion of the plots after induction period and used for the calculation of the activation parameters for the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane by using Arrhenius plot (insets in Fig. 5). The Arrhenius activation energy is found to be E a =58±2 and 59±2kJmol−1 for the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with 5.0 and 20mM Ru(acac)3 plus 3 equivalents oleylamine per ruthenium, respectively. Compared to the activation energy of 85±2kJmol−1 obtained for the same reaction starting with sole ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate [31], the addition, of 3 equivalent oleylamine per mole of ruthenium lowers the activation energy for the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane enormously. A similar effect is also observed in the catalytic activity of the Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent oleylamine system compared to that of the sole Ru(acac)3. The average value of turnover frequency in the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane at 60.0±0.1°C is increased from 17 to 77.8h−1 when the reaction is started with the addition of 3 equivalent oleylamine per mole ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate (vide infra) [31]. Lifetime of the catalyst comprising Ru(acac)3 plus 3 equivalent oleylamine was measured by determining the total turnover number (TTON) in hydrogen generation from the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene solution at 60.0±0.1°C. As seen in Fig. 6 , the catalyst formed from the reduction of Ru(acac)3 in the presence of 3 equivalent oleylamine provides more than 15,000 turnovers over 193h with a constant TOF value of 77.8 (molH2)(molRu)−1 (h)−1 in hydrogen generation from the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene solution at 60.0±0.1°C. Note that the catalyst was still active generating hydrogen gas at the same initial rate in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane when the experiment was terminated after 193h. These results clearly show that the active catalyst formed from Ru(acac)3 and oleylamine has approximately 5 times higher catalytic activity and at least 9 times longer lifetime than that of the sole Ru(acac)3 (TTO=1700) [31] in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene solution at 60.0±0.1°C. It is also noteworthy that the TOF remains constant in the course of catalytic reaction; even the increasing concentration of cyclic product do not affect the catalyst. This is remarkable since the turnover frequency usually decreases as the catalytic reaction proceeds and therefore, it is almost traditional to report just the initial TOF value. A mercury poisoning experiment was performed to confirm that the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 plus 3 equivalent oleylamine is homogeneous [40]. The hydrogen generation rate in the system comprising Ru(acac)3 plus 3 equivalent oleylamine was not affected by the addition of 700 equivalents of mercury to the reaction solution after 50% conversion of dimethylamine borane in toluene at 60.0±0.1°C. This observation indicates unequivocally that the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 plus 3 equivalent oleylamine is a homogeneous catalysis. 4 Identification of catalytically active ruthenium(II) species The enhancement in the catalytic activity by adding 3 equivalent oleylamine to the precatalyst solution of Ru(acac)3 is readily attributed to the formation of a new ruthenium species. In order to isolate the new ruthenium species, either in its catalytically active form or in a more stable form, after the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane the volatiles were removed in vacuum and the residue was dissolved in a mixture of hexane and dichloromethane. Upon cooling the solution to −20°C, the cyclic dehydrogenation product [(CH3)2NBH2]2 of dimethylamine borane was precipitated out from the solution. After the removal of precipitate by decantation, the supernatant solution was dried in vacuum leaving a residue containing the ruthenium catalyst, which was characterized by UV–vis, FT-IR, 1H, 13C NMR and Mass Spectroscopies. 4.1 UV–vis electronic absorption spectra UV–vis electronic absorption spectrum of sole Ru(acac)3 at the beginning of the catalytic reaction shows three prominent absorption bands at 270, 350 and 510nm, while the solid residue gives two absorption bands at 288 and 355nm in the spectrum (Fig. 7 ). In the course of catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane the absorption bands of ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate gradually loose intensity and ultimately are replaced by new bands of catalytically active ruthenium species. These new absorption features can be attributed to a ruthenium(II) species, considering its similarity to those reported for octahedral complexes of ruthenium(II), cis-[Ru(acac)2{P(OMe)3}2] [42], [Ru(en)2IP]2+ (IP: imidazo[4,5-f][1,10]phenanthroline) [43], and Ru(II)-polypyridyl complexes with five- and six-membered chelate rings [44]. 4.2 Mass spectrum Mass spectrum of the residue obtained after the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane shows a molecular ion peak at m/z =834.56 which can be assigned to a ruthenium(II) complex with the composition of [Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] (Fig. 8 a). The high-resolution mass spectrum in Fig. 8b shows the isotope distribution for the molecular peak which matches well with the simulated isotope pattern for the molecular formula C46H88N2O4Ru given in Fig. 8c. 1H and 13C NMR Spectra: The 13C NMR spectrum of the residue obtained after catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate plus 3 equivalent oleylamine is displayed in Fig. 9 a. One can clearly see only one signal at δ 160.56ppm for carbonyl carbons and one signal at 97.52ppm for the olefinic carbons of the two acac ligands. This indicates unequivocally that two acac ligands are equivalent which is only possible in the trans arrangement of two oleylamine ligands in the octahedral ruthenium(II) complex. Thus one can conclude the existence of trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] shown in Fig. 10 . In consistence with the trans arrangement of amine ligands, two signals are observed at 129.90 and 130.91ppm for the olefinic carbons of the two oleylamine ligands. All the other signals are readily assigned to the oleylamine and acetylacetonato ligands in line with the trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] structure [43,44] as given in the experimental section. 1H NMR spectrum of the residue obtained after catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate plus 3 equivalent oleylamine (Fig. 9b) shows signals readily assigned to the hydrogen atoms of the oleylamine and acetylacetonato ligands in trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] complex, as given in Section 2. 4.3 FT-IR spectrum The FT-IR spectrum of the residue obtained after catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate plus 3 equivalent oleylamine is displayed in Fig. 11 . The most prominent absorption bands at 3318–3205 (broad), 1626, and 1516–1313cm−1 are due to the NH, CO and CC stretching, respectively, confirming the presence of the oleylamine and acac ligands in trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2]. We were able to show that the residue obtained after catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate plus 3 equivalent oleylamine contains essentially the trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] complex. It is not known whether this is the active catalyst or a stable form of it, which can be formed from the catalytically active species during the isolation. The catalytic activity of the trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] complex was tested in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane (Fig. 12 ). Since the complex is not pure, its activity cannot be quantified. However, it shows some activity in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. It is noteworthy that the activity decreases quite fast particularly towards the end of reaction. Nevertheless, complete dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane could be achieved. The decrease in catalytic activity might be due to impurities in the residue used in the test. 5 Conclusion In summary, our study on the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 and oleylamine precatalyst leads to the following conclusions and insights, some of which were previously unavailable: (i) Adding 3 equivalent oleylamine per mole of ruthenium into the precatalyst solution of Ru(acac)3 increases both the catalytic activity (by a factor of ∼5) and the lifetime (by a factor of >9) of the catalyst compared to the ones obtained by using sole Ru(acac)3 [31] in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene at 60.0±0.1°C. (ii) The most interesting feature of the present study is the simplicity of preparing the catalytic materials as the precatalyst system is composed of two commercially available compounds, ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate and oleylamine. (iii) Oleylamine replaces one acac ligand in Ru(acac)3 whereby ruthenium(III) is reduced to ruthenium(II). This is supported by the identification of trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] as major component of the solid residue obtained after the catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. (iv) 1 equivalent oleylamine might be used to scavenge 1 equivalent H+ produced from the reduction of ruthenium(III) to ruthenium(II). (v) Increasing the concentration of Ru(acac)3 and applying higher temperature lead to a decrease in the induction time during which the catalyst is formed from the reaction of Ru(acac)3 and oleylamine. (vi) Dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 and oleylamine is first-order with respect to both the catalyst and substrate concentrations; different from the case of using sole Ru(acac)3 precatalyst whereby the reaction is essentially independent of substrate concentration [31]. (vii) The activation energy of catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent oleylamine (E a =58±2kJmol−1) is much lower than that obtained for the same reaction by using the sole Ru(acac)3 precursor (E a =85±2kJmol−1) [31]. (viii) The precatalyst system comprising Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent oleylamine provides a total turnover number of 15,000 over 8 days in hydrogen generation from the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane before deactivation, which is nine times higher than that obtained by the sole Ru(acac)3 precursor (1700 turnovers over 100h) [31]. (ix) The catalyst formed from the Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent oleylamine precursor has high catalytic activity (TOF=77.8h−1) and longer lifetime than the previously reported best homogeneous [45] and heterogeneous [22] catalysts. (x) The TOF value remains constant in the course of catalytic reaction; this is unusual since the turnover frequency usually decreases as the catalytic reaction proceeds and therefore, it is almost traditional to report just the initial TOF value. The increasing concentration of cyclic product do not affect the catalyst, most likely because of its inability to coordinate the ruthenium center. Since the system doesn't have any other strong nucleophile which would attack the active catalyst, no deactivation of catalyst is observed in the course of the catalytic reaction. Hence, under the reaction conditions the catalyst has log lifetime and can be used without activity loss. The remarkable increase in the catalytic activity and lifetime of the catalyst obained by adding oleylamine to the precatalyst solution of ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate is the most significant achievement in the present study compared to the previous report [31]. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we report the results of our study on the homogeneous catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in the presence of Ru(acac)3 and oleylamine (OAm) in toluene solution. The precatalyst system comprising Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent OAm shows the high catalytic activity in hydrogen generation from dimethylamine borane solution. Monitoring the hydrogen evolution shows the presence of an induction period during which the homogeneous catalyst is formed, and then the hydrogen evolution continues almost linearly until the complete dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane. UV–vis spectroscopic observation implies on the formation of a ruthenium(II) species. Using UV–vis, FTIR, Mass, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopies we could identify the presence of trans-[Ru(acac)2(OAm)2] in the solid residue obtained after the catalytic reaction. This complex might be a stable form of the active catalyst as it shows similar catalytic activity in dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane as before. The precatalyst system comprising Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent OAm provides 15,000 turnovers over 8 days with a constant turnover frequency of TOF=77.8h−1 in hydrogen generation from the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane in toluene solution at 60.0±0.1°C. Adding 3 equivalent OAm per Ru into the precatalyst solution increases the catalytic activity by a factor of ∼5 and the lifetime of the catalyst by a factor of >9 compared to the ones obtained by using sole Ru(acac)3. Kinetics of catalytic dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with Ru(acac)3 and 3 equivalent OAm in toluene solution were studied depending on catalyst concentration, substrate concentration and temperature. The catalytic reaction was found to be first-order with respect to each of both Ru(acac)3 and dimethylamine borane concentrations. The activation energy for the catalytic dehydrogenation is E a =58±2kJ/mol.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active and long lived homogeneous catalyst for the dehydrogenation of dimethylamine borane starting with ruthenium(III) acetylacetonate and oleylamine precatalyst
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
